image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: Victoria Cross recipient Ben Roberts-Smith's decision to sue the publishers of the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age and The Canberra Times, and three journalists, in the Federal Court over a series of articles published in 2018 backfires.

title.children: Judge throws out Ben Roberts-Smith's defamation case, backs media reports of war crimes, murders

image.altText: very red map of australia

items.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology forecasts parched conditions across virtually all of Australia this winter as a double whammy of drought-linked climate drivers brew in waters to the west and east.

title.children: 'Worrying' warm, dry winter tipped for virtually all of Australia

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith surrounded by journalist outside of court

items.synopsis: If Ben Roberts-Smith thought his reputation was in tatters before today, it's hard to imagine what state it's in now, after a Federal Court judge threw out his defamation lawsuit and ruled the most serious imputations made against him had been proven.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith tried to clear his name — it proved to be an expensive own goal

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith dressed in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Justice Anthony Besanko delivers a devastating blow to war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith, who had been suing three newspapers and three journalists for defamation over articles alleging he committed war crimes in Afghanistan. This is how it unfolded

title.children: As it happened: Australia's most decorated war veteran cops devastating court blow, costs will 'follow inevitably'

image.altText: Safety tape is seen cordoning off a four-storey building with visible fire damage to the top floor

items.synopsis: The man accused of murder over the fire that killed five people is already in custody, having been charged with two counts of arson.

title.children: Murder charges laid over fatal Wellington Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: Journalists gather around a woman giving a press conference.

items.synopsis: ACT Victims of Crime Commissioner Heidi Yates says walking into court with the alleged victim during Bruce Lehrmann's trial was one of her statutory duties.

title.children: Victims' advocate defends her show of support for Brittany Higgins during rape trial

image.altText: Phil Egan looks stern standing near a river.

items.synopsis: Indigenous advocates have slammed the AFL's handling of the Hawthorn probe, and urged the league to become a "cultural leader" by addressing alleged mistreatment of First Nations players across the sporting code.

title.children: AFL urged to become 'cultural leader' amid fallout from Hawthorn probe

image.altText: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in an illustration.

items.synopsis: The European Union and the United States say they expect to draft a voluntary code of conduct on artificial intelligence "within weeks" in the hope that other democracies will sign on.

title.children: EU and US set to advance global AI code of conduct amid 'extinction' warning

image.altText: Melbourne OPBD - POI 1

items.synopsis: Police say they are looking for two men who allegedly tricked a vulnerable passer-by into giving them his rent and pension money by pretending to tell his fortune.

title.children: Police launch appeal after vulnerable man conned out of $1,700 in fortune-telling scam

image.altText: Four young children smiling and laughing

items.synopsis: Charmaine Harris McLeod, her two daughters, Aaleyn, 6, and Matilda, 5, and her two sons Wyatt, 4, and Zaidok, 2, died after their car collided with a truck near Kingaroy in May, 2019.

title.children: Inquest hears Charmaine McLeod claimed husband raped her and her children in years prior to fatal crash

image.altText: A man in a suit walks down court house steps.

items.synopsis: Two men who were throwing potatoes out a car window at pedestrians in what they considered to be a "prank" are jailed for seriously injuring an e-scooter rider, who had to have his eye removed.

title.children: Two men jailed for throwing potatoes out of car, seriously injuring e-scooter rider, who had to have eye removed

image.altText: Rosemary Walker solo

items.synopsis: National house prices lifted sharply in May, according to data from CoreLogic. Sydney continues to lead the recovery, with rises across the capital cities, as the number of properties advertised for sale fell further.

title.children: Rosemary paid $35k for a modest Sydney home. When it went to auction 45 years later, she thought she 'was going to faint'

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt looks at the camera. Behind him, lights hang from a rafter.

items.synopsis: Corey O'Connell went missing near Jalbarragup, south east of Nannup, in June 2021, with his abandoned car found nearby.

title.children: Police confirm death of missing WA man Corey O'Connell after human remains found

image.altText: Upwards shot of the BHP building in Perth.

items.synopsis: Mining giant BHP admits it has underpaid almost 30,000 workers, dating back to 2010, and it will cost more than $400 million to make amends.

title.children: 'Deeply sorry': Mining giant BHP admits underpaying almost 30,000 workers

image.altText: Glass of milk at a farm with two dairy cows behind it.

items.synopsis: As opening prices from the country's major milk processors were slowly released over the past two weeks, news they have slashed offers to farmers have sent sour waves of anger rippling through the industry.

title.children: Dairy farmers reeling after major milk processors slash price offerings by up to 10 per cent

image.altText: Libby Chaplin stands next to a battery recharging station, which has a sticker that says 'Electric Highway Tasmania'

items.synopsis: As Australia passes the milestone of 100,000 electric vehicles on our roads, an environmental downside is looming: huge numbers of batteries that could end up in landfill.

title.children: The triple threat posed by lithium batteries means electric vehicles risk a major downside

image.altText: Noel Payne looking at the camera sitting on a bicycle in a backyard.

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court justice concludes Rebecca Payne suffered more than a decade of "abhorrent" abuse from her husband but there was "no legal justification" for the killing.

title.children: Woman sentenced to 16 years' jail for murdering abusive husband with drug-laced biscuits

image.altText: Head of Wagner Group military company Yevgeny Prigozhin speaks to fighters in a forest area.

items.synopsis: Russia's most powerful mercenary, Yevgeny Prigozhin, asks prosecutors to investigate whether senior Russian defence officials committed any "crime" before or during the war in Ukraine.

title.children: Wagner chief calls for investigation into 'crimes' of top Russian defence officials

image.altText: A selfie photo of four, including male and female parent and two daughters

items.synopsis: Bendigo teenager Harriet Caldwell was active and healthy four weeks ago. She was stretching, getting ready to go to basketball training when she suddenly couldn't feel her legs after feeling a pop in her back.

title.children: Harriet was getting ready for basketball training when she lost feeling in her legs

image.altText: A police officer's torso showing a body cam

items.synopsis: A woman's "lonely death" of starvation in the suburbs of an Australian capital city raised "several issues", including with police inaction, a Tasmanian coroner has said.

title.children: Woman starved to death in unit shortly after police welfare check, coroner finds

image.altText: Water flows from a drinking fountain.

items.synopsis: Drinking taps, water fountains or bubblers; whatever you call them, there is a divide within the community over how hygienic they are to use.

title.children: Some people love them, others avoid them at all costs; but is there a health risk from using drinking fountains?

image.altText: Black and white cows under a tree

items.synopsis: Cows that eat chocolate don't produce chocolate milk, but it's pretty close. Reject confectionery bars are being eaten by dairy cows in a win for both their food requirements and for reducing landfill.

title.children: These dairy cows crave chocolates and lollies — so it's no surprise their milk is used to make flavoured drinks

image.altText: The Russian Embassy site in Yarralumla, Canberra.

items.synopsis: The National Capital Authority has failed to have a lease agreement for a new Russian embassy in Canberra torn up.

title.children: Court rules Russia can have 'quiet enjoyment' of Canberra land that authorities had said to vacate

image.altText: Authorities say the child was carried from the burning building but could not be revived

items.synopsis: Authorities say the child was carried from the burning building but could not be revived.

title.children: Detectives investigate after child under five dies in Alice Springs house fire

image.altText: A drone shot of a town by a lake with snow.

items.synopsis: The NSW Snowy Mountains town has seen the highest rise in median house price of any town or suburb in NSW, according to new data from Proptrack.

title.children: Locals say they've been priced out of Jindabyne as house prices more than double over five years

image.altText: J MILLA holds an Aboriginal flag, he is on stage

items.synopsis: J-MILLA's poignant and at times confronting lyrics have brought the young Indigenous rapper critical acclaim and a burgeoning social media following. His concert in the small, remote Northern Territory community of Wadeye will be going global.

title.children: Rapper set to make history in tiny Indigenous town

image.altText: A french bulldog puppy with large ears

items.synopsis: Police said four other puppies that were in the same room were not touched during the alleged burglary, and a man and woman in their 50s remained sleeping in the home throughout the incident.

title.children: Police investigate alleged theft of French bulldog puppy valued at $15,000 in regional Victoria

image.altText: medium clear jellyfish on a wet sand beach.

items.synopsis: Lifesavers warn residents and visitors in the Northern Territory to take precautions against box jellyfish this dry season after a child is stung at a popular Darwin beach.

title.children: Boy stung by box jellyfish at Darwin's Casuarina Beach, prompting dry season warning

image.altText: COVID-19 image

items.synopsis: Scientists still don't know what causes it, how to treat it — or even how to best diagnose it. So how do we know if we have long COVID?

title.children: Scientists say these are the 12 symptoms that reveal when COVID becomes long COVID

image.altText: A drawing of a house under construction

items.synopsis: What happens when you hear that your building company has gone broke and work on your half-built house comes to a grinding halt?

title.children: Thinking of building a home? Here's what you need to know about the crisis in construction

image.altText: A young woman leans against the steel border force, looking into the camera.

items.synopsis: Belarus was accused of manufacturing a refugee crisis on the European Union's doorstep two years ago. Now, as close ally Russia wages war nearby, asylum seekers are again at the fence.

title.children: 'I have children who will die if we stay in the forest': Is Putin behind a mysterious migrant crisis?

image.altText: A blonde white woman in a red scarf and navy jacket, Penny, cuts a cara cara orange open with a knife in an orchard.

items.synopsis: New varieties of citrus like cara cara navels and blood oranges are growing in popularity, but farmers say supermarkets need to stock more to grow demand.

title.children: Pink is the new orange with consumers hungry for photo-worthy new citrus varieties

image.altText: a man standing in a field of cannabis plants

items.synopsis: Hemp advocates hail the much-maligned crop as the billion-dollar saviour to Victoria's ailing timber industry, but politicians are concerned the industry could pave the way to legalising cannabis.

title.children: Is cannabis the new timber? Advocates want industrial hemp to solve Australia’s housing crisis
